linkTarget.anchoringText: This study presents a polymer injection pilot in the Desfiladero Bayo field, at the border of the Mendoza and Neuquen provinces in Argentina (Figure 1)

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Location of the Desfiladero Bayo Field and the polymer pilot (red)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location of the Desfiladero Bayo Field and the polymer pilot (red)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Rayoso Fm. consists of ephemeral fluvial sandstones of great lateral continuity with reservoir permeabilities varying from the low md through to darcy. The intermediate facies (lower fine and fine grained sandstones, yellow and orange facies code in Figure 2) have permeability ranging from 50-400md and contains the majority of the remaining recoverable oil. The darcy sands (medium sandstone, red in Figure 2) in most cases show connectivity at scales beyond that of the injector producer pairs, probably acting as short cuts for injection water, especially due to the high viscosity of the resident oil.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: 3D Model and cross-section of the facies distribution through the pilot zone in the Desfiladero Bayo Field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: 3D Model and cross-section of the facies distribution through the pilot zone in the Desfiladero Bayo Field.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Rayoso Fm. has also a very good relationship between facies and permeability variations since little diagenesis has affected the rock. Figure 3 shows permeability through the same cross-section; darcy permeabilities are located in the upper stratigraphy while 50-400mD permeabilities dominate the rest of the reservoir intervals.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: 3D Model and cross-section of the permeability through the center of the pilot pone in the Desfiladero Bayo field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: 3D Model and cross-section of the permeability through the center of the pilot pone in the Desfiladero Bayo field.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The pilot was designed to fit in as much as possible with the existing well pattern on the field. To this end, the pilot was designed as a line drive with a line of 3 injectors lying to the east and west of a line of 3 producers. Figure 4 shows the polymer pilot design. New wells were only drilled to the Rayoso Fm. while existing wells were isolated from the underlying Agrio and Troncoso (Huitrin) Formations.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: A) Well design of the polymer pilot. B) Relative location of the wells on Desfiladero Bayo pilot showing the central pilot zone (Blue) and peripheral pilot zone (Red)

formatted-caption.caption-text: A) Well design of the polymer pilot. B) Relative location of the wells on Desfiladero Bayo pilot showing the central pilot zone (Blue) and peripheral pilot zone (Red)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Well design of the polymer pilot
Relative location of the wells on Desfiladero Bayo pilot showing the central pilot zone (Blue) and peripheral pilot zone (Red)

linkTarget.anchoringText: One primary risk of injecting potentially at above parting pressure is that the fracturing will be uncontrolled and could result in the creation of a induced fractured that directly connects the injector to the producer, this amplifying the problem of shortcutting rather than increasing sweep as desired. To minimize this effect, one of the design guidelines was for the direction of principal stress to be perpendicular to the principal flow direction, so that induced fractures would preferentially travel to the adjacent injector instead of the producer. How this arrangement is expected to work in the polymer pilot area is shown in Figure 5.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Expected induced fracturing direction and simulated pressures in polymer pilot January 2025

formatted-caption.caption-text: Expected induced fracturing direction and simulated pressures in polymer pilot January 2025

linkTarget.anchoringText: It was decided to keep the flowing bottomhole pressure on the producer wells in the central as low as possible at all times, this normally between 5-15 bar as determined by level data. There is the issue that this is below the bubble point of the reservoir of 35 bar and indeed the limited data available on gas production does show that the producing GOR is above solution GOR. However, since the initial reservoir pressure in the pilot area was only 38 bar, it was felt that keeping the wells producing above bubble point would choke production too much. An example of the measured flowing bottom hole pressure for the PP-1 (Figure 6).

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Measured flowing bottomhole pressure of PP-1in the pilot.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Measured flowing bottomhole pressure of PP-1in the pilot.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 7 shows the combined oil and water history matches achieved on the three producer wells of the central pilot. Figure 8 shows the RFT matches available for the wells located within the central pilot zone. It should be noted that no local property modifiers are used to improve the quality of the history match of individual wells. All variables are only changed per reservoir cycle or per facies. A close match was obtained in rates while the pressures were well matched in the more productive intervals.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: History match of the three producer wells lying in the pilot.

formatted-caption.caption-text: History match of the three producer wells lying in the pilot.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 7 shows the combined oil and water history matches achieved on the three producer wells of the central pilot. Figure 8 shows the RFT matches available for the wells located within the central pilot zone. It should be noted that no local property modifiers are used to improve the quality of the history match of individual wells. All variables are only changed per reservoir cycle or per facies. A close match was obtained in rates while the pressures were well matched in the more productive intervals.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: RFT match of the wells in the central pilot area

formatted-caption.caption-text: RFT match of the wells in the central pilot area

linkTarget.anchoringText: However the unknowns of this reservoir, specifically the production and injection history, precluded this option. The production data of individual pilot wells was measured periodically and by observation of oil and water levels in a test tank. This approach is not particularly accurate on a single test basis and the data was expected and did show significant scatter. Looking at historical water cut (Figure 9)

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Historical water cut from a well on the pilot, note the scatter

formatted-caption.caption-text: Historical water cut from a well on the pilot, note the scatter

linkTarget.anchoringText: Full-field modelling of the Desfiladero Bayo Field had shown the presence of two OWC’s in the Rayoso Fm. confirmed by multiple wells targeting deeper reservoir in lower structural positions and subsequently by history matching (Figure 10).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Saturation model and the Two OWCs seen in the dynamic pilot sector model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Saturation model and the Two OWCs seen in the dynamic pilot sector model

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 11 shows that a clear oil response is seen in the resistivity log in the highest quality facies while in the deepest intermediate facies, the resistivity is the same as off structure responses in wells that have only tested water. Also the sands lying in between these sands seem to show a clear resistivity peak but not of the same magnitude as the response in the highest quality facies. So these smaller resistivity peaks could represent a number of possibilities;

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Sandstone intervals of PP-1 and its logs

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sandstone intervals of PP-1 and its logs

linkTarget.anchoringText: Reservoir quality and water saturation vary stratigraphically across the formation and depending on facies types and in particular, the initial and current water saturation in the thinner intermediate facies was not clear. A log section of a recently drilled well on the Rayoso Fm. is shown in Figure 12. Intermediate quality sands were initially interpreted to be in the transition zone while the highest quality facies was assumed to be at irreducible saturation (Thompson et al. 2016).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: The injection profile of PI-2 during the execution of the water injection phase of the pilot.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The injection profile of PI-2 during the execution of the water injection phase of the pilot.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Additionally history matching the tracers in particular suggested that all the facies contained oil as the transit times between injector producer pairs were too short to represent an even sweep. Also to achieve the historical gross rates seen in the pilot producer wells, it was clear that the end points of the water relative permeability curve needed to be comparatively high in at least once facies. Therefore the relative permeability in the highest quality facies was modified to both have a higher end point to water and a lower Corey exponent (Figure 15B). An example of the good match of tracer concentration from PI-2 to PP-2 that was obtained is shown in Figure 13.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Tracer match between PI-2 and PP-2.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Tracer match between PI-2 and PP-2.

linkTarget.anchoringText: To match the time to tracer breakthorugh, it is necessary for the water/tracer to pass through only a limited thickness of the reservoir (Figure 14).

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Simulated tracer concentrations at the peak P1-2 tracer response in PP-2 in January 2016.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Simulated tracer concentrations at the peak P1-2 tracer response in PP-2 in January 2016.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Additionally history matching the tracers in particular suggested that all the facies contained oil as the transit times between injector producer pairs were too short to represent an even sweep. Also to achieve the historical gross rates seen in the pilot producer wells, it was clear that the end points of the water relative permeability curve needed to be comparatively high in at least once facies. Therefore the relative permeability in the highest quality facies was modified to both have a higher end point to water and a lower Corey exponent (Figure 15B). An example of the good match of tracer concentration from PI-2 to PP-2 that was obtained is shown in Figure 13.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: A) History matched relative permeability for intermediate facies B) H-M for highest quality facies

formatted-caption.caption-text: A) History matched relative permeability for intermediate facies B) H-M for highest quality facies

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: History matched relative permeability for intermediate facies

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Figure 16 we see the available experimental relative permeabilities for the Rayoso formation compared with the history matched relative permeabilities. Both history matched water relative permeability curves lie within the range of experimental data. The experimental curves with the higher end points correspond to cores with larger pore sizes, these thought to represent the highest quality facies.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Experimentally derived relative permeability data for the Rayoso Fm. and the history matched relative permeabilities

formatted-caption.caption-text: Experimentally derived relative permeability data for the Rayoso Fm. and the history matched relative permeabilities

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Figure 17 we see the sightings of the tracer injected in March 2015 during the water injection phase of the pilot. Although connectivity is demonstrated between 5 of the 6 injector producer pairs, there was a concern that tracer PI-3 was not seen at producer PP-3 despite the fact that it is located closer to PI-3 than the other wells, the cause of this needed to be identified.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Evolution of tracers injected with water

formatted-caption.caption-text: Evolution of tracers injected with water

linkTarget.anchoringText: From the pilot monitoring plan, transient flow profiles carried out monthly, showed initial water injection entering the deeper depleted reservoir layers (Figure 18). The irregular allocation of water in the injection tracer logs of PI-3 suggests that the impact of free gas was affecting the movement of the injection water, even after the dosing of the first tracers in March 2015. In fact the injection profile only stabilizes around the end of 2015. As the gas bearing low pressure layers were filled up, water injection moved on to the higher permeability oil containing intervals.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Historical injection tracer logs for PI-3

formatted-caption.caption-text: Historical injection tracer logs for PI-3

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the original iteration of the dynamic model, in the absence of recent RFT data and the presence of two water injectors nearby, it was not realized that the offtake in this part of the pilot zone had been high enough to bring this part of the pilot zone before bubble point. Increasing the offtake of the PI-3 when it was a producer and other wells in this area led to the creation of local secondary gas caps in the model when the reservoir was exploited by primary (Figure 19).

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Simulated gas saturation during primary depletion of the Rayoso in 1997

formatted-caption.caption-text: Simulated gas saturation during primary depletion of the Rayoso in 1997

linkTarget.anchoringText: When tracer was injected into the simulation model with free gas in the vicinity of PI-3, water injected into PI-3 predominantly went in the direction of the gas cap and the structural high around SLP-2 rather than displacing oil towards PP-3. In Figure 20 we can see the simulated PI-3 tracer saturations a few months after dosage after ensuring a gas cap is created in the vicinity of SLP-2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Simulated PI-3 tracer saturation in September 2015

formatted-caption.caption-text: Simulated PI-3 tracer saturation in September 2015

linkTarget.anchoringText: When PP-1 was cored, although it showed oil in all the net sands, saturation logs showed a water bearing interval in the main target interval as seen in figure 21. However when the well was brought onstream. it produced with a 98% water cut.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: Well logs and core of PP-1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well logs and core of PP-1

linkTarget.anchoringText: From the history matching process we learnt that injection water is strongly directed to this highest quality facies and in PP-1, the thickness of this highest quality facies was more than in other wells of the pilot. Also it lay near to the injector PI-1 which has been injecting water since October 1997. The modelled location of the highest quality facies combined with the location of PP-1 and neighboring wells is shown in Figure 22

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: Cross section of PI-4-PP-1 & PI-1 showing the location of the highest quality and intermediate facies

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross section of PI-4-PP-1 & PI-1 showing the location of the highest quality and intermediate facies

linkTarget.anchoringText: With the relative permeability of this invaded zone being highly favorable to water this led to the production of PP-1 being dominated by this water bearing layer. Since PP-1 has a higher proportion of high quality facies compared to the other two pilot producers, it was more adversely affected by the water channeling effect of the high quality facies. The simulated water saturation and the corresponding well flow profiles in September 2014 (Figure 23).

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: Cross section of PI-4, PP-1 & PI-1 showing simulated water saturations in September 2014 and the simulated oil and water profile of PP-1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross section of PI-4, PP-1 & PI-1 showing simulated water saturations in September 2014 and the simulated oil and water profile of PP-1

linkTarget.anchoringText: In figure 24, PI-3 communicates first with PP-3, this confirming that the impact of gas on the pilot had been eliminated by water injection by the time the second tracers were dosed in December 2016. To date, in January 2018 three sets of the second set of tracers have been seen in the pilot producers yet no polymer has been seen by January 2018. It is obvious that the explanation is polymer retention.

image-wrap.label: Figure 24
image-wrap.caption: Sighting of the second set of tracers as of January 2018

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sighting of the second set of tracers as of January 2018

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 25 shows that in the dynamic model, although the simulated invasion of tracer and polymer are similar, the tracer added during polymer injection still fingers more towards the producer than the polymer, the cause of this in the dynamic model is that the low concentration fingers of polymer are assumed to be retained by the formation, this probably is also the situation in reality.

image-wrap.label: Figure 25
image-wrap.caption: Estimated polymer and tracer concentrations in the model as of January 2018 between PI-6 and PP-3

formatted-caption.caption-text: Estimated polymer and tracer concentrations in the model as of January 2018 between PI-6 and PP-3

linkTarget.anchoringText: In figure 26A is the expected polymer concentration in PP-2 according to the dynamic model with the initial polymer retention estimate used in the dynamic model. In January 2018 we were expecting to see a polymer concentration of 0.05 kg/m3 as compared to the predominant injection concentration of 1.2 kg/m3. However the minimum concentration at which we expect to see polymer by a method which involves dropping Kaolinite into the produced samples is 1-2 ppm in the laboratory although in the field the detection limit is thought to be closer to 10ppm.

image-wrap.label: Figure 26
image-wrap.caption: A) Estimated produced polymer concentration in PP-2, B) Original and revised polymer retention estimates

formatted-caption.caption-text: A) Estimated produced polymer concentration in PP-2, B) Original and revised polymer retention estimates

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the dynamic model, it is estimated that had water flooding had been allowed to continue, the water cut in the three producers would have reached nearly 95% by January 2018 while in reality the average water in the three producers has predominantly remained between 92-93% as show in Figure 27. Superimposing the expected polymer injection and waterflooding forecasts on the historical water cut data of the 3 producer wells of the pilot shows that the water cut trend until January 2018 is more likely to be following the polymer injection scenario forecast rather than the water flooding forecast.

image-wrap.label: Figure 27
image-wrap.caption: Comparisons of the actual and forecast water cuts for the three pilot producers

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparisons of the actual and forecast water cuts for the three pilot producers

linkTarget.anchoringText: As the model is updated, if it shows that the expected increment is less than previously expected, remedial action needs to be taken to hopefully rectify the situation. In Figure 28 we can see the forecasts for oil production by water injection and polymer injections are shown as well as the actual combined oil production data from the three producer wells in the pilot. Note: The waterflood forecast starts from February 2016 as after this date the injection rates in the pilot injectors were reduced while the polymer forecast is from August 2017.

image-wrap.label: Figure 28
image-wrap.caption: Waterflood and polymer forecasts for oil rate for the polymer pilot as of January 2018 and the historical oil rate.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Waterflood and polymer forecasts for oil rate for the polymer pilot as of January 2018 and the historical oil rate.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The model was also used to establish the optimum polymer dosage. What was clear from the model was that due to a very adverse mobility ratio and the high heterogeneity in the reservoir, a very high viscosity polymer would be preferred to overcome both negative traits. Unfortunately, the optimum polymer viscosity cannot be injected into the reservoir at economic rates. Hence a decision was made to inject with the highest viscosity that could achieve 100 m3/day per injector. However even with the 1.2 kg/m3 or 1.5 kg/m3 we are injecting today, we do not achieve a uniform displacement according the simulation model (Figure 29).

image-wrap.label: Figure 29
image-wrap.caption: A cross section of the polymer flood status at estimated first polymer breakthrough.

formatted-caption.caption-text: A cross section of the polymer flood status at estimated first polymer breakthrough.

linkTarget.anchoringText: This meant that it was now possible to consider optimization of the pilot. Utilizing the model it could be seen that the prolonged injection of water prior to polymer injection meant that the relative permeability in the highest quality facies was higher to water than was the case at initial conditions. By comparing Figures 30A and B, it is posisble to observe that that the injected water has increased the relative permeability significantly in the highest quality facies, comparatively, very little water is estimated to have entered the intermediate quality facies leading to a situation where the relative permeabilites in the highest quality facies are about 10x higher than in the intermediate quality facies.

image-wrap.label: Figure 30
image-wrap.caption: A) Cross sections in January 2018 across PI-6, PP-3 and PI-3 simulated water relative permeability B) Modelled permeability

formatted-caption.caption-text: A) Cross sections in January 2018 across PI-6, PP-3 and PI-3 simulated water relative permeability B) Modelled permeability

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Cross sections in January 2018 across PI-6, PP-3 and PI-3 simulated water relative permeability

linkTarget.anchoringText: The highest quality facies have water transmissibility about 50-200 times greater than that expected in the intermediate facies (Figure 31). Bearing in mind that the oil has an estimated visocisty of 19cp, it will require injecting polymer with an unrelisitically high viscosity to fully overcome this bias in the transmissibility to water. Consequently the simulation model is being used to estimate what combination(s) of injection rate and injected polymer viscosity offer the best return

image-wrap.label: Figure 31
image-wrap.caption: Estimated water transmissibility in January 2018, permeability multiplied by relative permeability to water

formatted-caption.caption-text: Estimated water transmissibility in January 2018, permeability multiplied by relative permeability to water
